question: Question_02_(b)
statement:
For \emph{n} ∈ \textbf{N}, let \emph{P}(\emph{n}) be the statement
"\emph{n} is divisible by 4", and let \emph{Q}(\emph{n}) be the
statement "\emph{n}\textsuperscript{2} + 1 is divisible by 3".

Write out in words the statement "\emph{P}(3) → \emph{Q}(4)", its
converse, and its contrapositive.
sols:
\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The statement
\end{itemize}

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
P(3) \Rightarrow Q(4)\end{align*} is \emph{``3 is divisible by 4 implies that 17
is divisible by 3''}.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The \textbf{converse} is
\end{itemize}

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
Q(4) \Rightarrow P(3)\end{align*} hence in words it is \emph{``17 is divisible by
3 implies that 3 is divisible by 4''}.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The \textbf{contrapositive} is
\end{itemize}

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\lnot Q(4) \Rightarrow \lnot P(3)\end{align*} In words this is \emph{``17 is not
divisible by 3 implies that 3 is not divisible by 4''}.
hints:
The \emph{converse} of the statement

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
A \Rightarrow B\end{align*} is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
B \Rightarrow A\end{align*}

The \emph{contrapositive} of the statement

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
A \Rightarrow B\end{align*} is

\begin{align*}\lnot B \Rightarrow \lnot A\end{align*}
